Hi Derek,

Derek James wrote:

>This question is directed at Colin, but I thought I would mention it
>in front of the group in case anyone else was interested.
>
>Colin, did you happen to carry out the phased searching approach with
>double pole balancing?  What would be your recommendations for the
>mean population complexity threshold for this experiment?
>  
>
First we need to distinguish between the three different double pole 
experiments as discussed in Ken's paper 1) double-pole, 2) double-pole 
without a velocity input and 3) as in 2 but with a modified fitness 
function that punishes rapid 'wiggling' of the poles - which apparently 
is a way of cheating, although I suspect this is a symptom of the 
physics model in use. Perhaps reducing the time increment and/or 
limiting the maximum velocity of the cart would be another way of 
resolving this problem, I'm not sure

If I remember correctly, solutions to 1 & 2  are typically evolved quite 
rapidly and therefore even with pruning switched on the complexity of 
the population won't rise enough to trigger it. (3) on the other hand is 
a trickier problem, but I'll have to check if pruning actually assists.

>We're probably going to end up duplicating double pole balancing in
>ANJI and trying a few different experiments, so we may have additional
>questions/issues.
>  
>
Sure, it's probably worth looking at both my double-pole source and 
Ken's (originally from elsewhere as Ken pointed out recently) as I think 
I did a bit of cleaning up and possibly some optimisation. Syntactically 
though the C++, Java and C# will be almost identical so porting is easy.

I'll get back to you w.r.t. pruning in problem (3).

Colin
